subject: Languages
title: Code-Switching: Speaking Two Languages at Once
description: A quick win: understand Code-Switching: Speaking Two Languages at Once.

hook.text: Bilinguals don't switch languages randomly. Code-switching follows precise grammatical rules that linguists study.

buildup.text: Spanglish, Hinglish, and Franglais are examples â€” speakers blend two languages seamlessly in one sentence.

discovery.text: Switches happen at grammatical boundaries â€” you can't swap languages in the middle of a word.

twist.text: Code-switching was long dismissed as 'lazy' or 'confused.' Linguists now know it requires greater skill.

climax.text: Far from being broken language, code-switching shows mastery of two grammars simultaneously.

punchline.text: Switching languages isn't confusion. It's the linguistic version of ambidexterity.
